Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Polyandry and Meiotic Drive in Drosophila neotestacea
Award.AbstractNarration:
Selfish genetic elements can promote their own transmission into the next generation, even if there is a cost to the inclusive fitness of the host. They are found in all eukaryotes, including, for example, mammals, plants, insects, birds, and fish. A classic example of a selfish genetic element is X-chromosome meiotic drive. 'X-drive' causes males to pass on the driving X chromosome to all of their offspring, which are all daughters. As a result of this biased transmission, theory predicts that X-drive could spread rapidly in a population and potentially drive it to extinction, due to a lack of males. Contrary to this prediction, X-drive is often observed at low to moderate frequencies in nature. The goal of this research is to understand how variation in female mating behavior may counteract the spread of X-drive. The investigators will perform experimental evolution with the fruit fly Drosophila neotestacea to provide new insights into how host behaviors can affect whether X-drive invades into a population, and the frequency at which it is maintained in a population.

The results of this study will deepen our understanding of how X-drive is maintained as a polymorphism in nature, and may be broadly applied to other species. Selfish genetic elements have been proposed for use in pest control regimes for insects that are vectors for devastating diseases. Thus, understanding the dynamics of driving chromosomes in nature may inform pest management practices. Additionally, this project will provide ample opportunities for undergraduate research training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Selfish genetic elements unfairly promote their own transmission to the next generation. As a result they can invade and spread rapidly through a host population even if they reduce the fitness of the host. Selfish genetic elements are found in all eukaryotes, and a classic example is X-chromosome meiotic drive. ‘X-drive’ occurs in males when the X-chromosome kills the sperm containing a Y-chromosome, and as a result all of his offspring of are daughters that also carry the selfish X-chromosome. Because this selfish chromosome is transmitted to 100% of the offspring, it is expected to spread rapidly; eventually, it may even cause extinction of the host population due to a lack of males. However, extinction does not always occur in nature. In this study we asked how host behavior affects the evolution of this selfish genetic element. In particular, we investigated the role of multiple mating in the dynamics of X-drive. We used the fruit fly Drosophila neotestacea, which harbors X-drive and has populations that differ in its frequency.

 

First, our results from both the field and the lab suggest that D. neotestacea females mate frequently and use the sperm from multiple males, not just the last male as is found in many other species. Second, we found that the fertility of X-drive carrier males is lower than wild-type males upon multiple mating, which is likely due to the death of half of their sperm. Third, we showed that natural populations where females mate more often also have a lower prevalence of X-drive. In sum, our results support the hypothesis that multiple mating is an important determinant of X-drive frequency in nature. Variation in the rate of female mating and the reduced male fertility of X-drive carriers may account for differences in prevalence not only among populations within a species but also among different species.

 

This funding provided invaluable research training to graduate and undergraduate students, with a focus on the inclusion of underrepresented minorities. This study provides us with a better understanding of how X-drive is maintained in nature, and the results can be broadly applied to other species. For instance, selfish genetic elements have been proposed for use in pest control regimes, and understanding the factors that influence their dynamics is important for their use in combating insects that are vectors for devastating diseases and that cause significant economic damage.
